12 things to do after installing Windows 10
05 Nov 2019, 07:00 by Dmitry Sazhko
How to configure the OS to work with it has become easier and more convenient.
1. Install updates



This is the first step you must take in the new system. Surely for the time that your computer was on the counter, Microsoft managed to release a lot of patches and corrections. The accumulated updates can be installed for a long time, so you should deal with it right away.
First, make sure your computer is connected to the Internet. Then select the ‚ÄúStart‚Äù menu and open ‚ÄúSettings‚Äù ‚Üí ‚ÄúWindows Update‚Äù ‚Üí ‚ÄúCheck for Updates‚Äù. Wait for the system to install all available updates.
2. Update drivers (optional)
As a rule, Windows 10 handles installing drivers automatically, so in most cases you can skip this step. But sometimes you still have to install them manually. For example, if you notice that some equipment - speakers, a video card, a web camera - does not work correctly with the driver that Windows 10 offered, it can help you with the free Snappy Driver Installer application.
3. Install a browser



If you feel that Edge is not for you, you should first install a more comfortable browser. You have a choice of Chrome, Firefox, Opera, Vivaldi and a ton of less popular options if you suddenly want exotic ones.

4. Protect the system with antivirus



Windows 10 comes with built-in Windows Defender, always on by default. In addition, if you purchased a computer with a preinstalled operating system, a trial version of some antivirus may also be installed on it.
Windows Defender is a good antivirus, which in most cases is enough to protect your home PC. However, it may not be enough to deal with possible network threats if you actively install new software and visit unverified sites. Fortunately, you have the opportunity to choose from the list of the best free antiviruses.
5. Remove unnecessary applications
Windows 10 comes with a large number of built-in and pre-installed applications from both Microsoft and the manufacturer of your computer. But you can delete what you do not plan to use to clear the place. To do this, open ‚ÄúOptions‚Äù ‚Üí ‚ÄúApplications‚Äù ‚Üí ‚ÄúApplications and Features‚Äù, and then right-click on an unnecessary program and select ‚ÄúDelete‚Äù.
6. Install the necessary applications
Now you need to install the software for everyday work. Here are free apps you can‚Äôt do without on your home computer.

Office suite: OpenOffice, LibreOffice, WPS Office.
PDF viewers: Sumatra, SlimPDF, PDF ‚Äë XChange.
Email client: Thunderbird, Mailspring, Sylpheed.
Password Manager: LastPass, KeePass, BitWarden.
Archiver: 7 ‚Äë Zip, PeaZip.
Messengers: Telegram, Skype.
Cloud Storage Client: Dropbox, Google Drive and others.
Note Manager: OneNote, Evernote, Simplenote.
Audio and video player: AIMP, foobar2000, MPC ‚Äë HC, VLC.

7. Disable autorun unnecessary applications



When you start Windows 10, applications that you may use infrequently will automatically start. And the fewer programs you have at startup, the faster the system will load. So it‚Äôs worth removing the extra ones from there.
To do this, launch the "Task Manager" with the combination Ctrl + Shift + Esc, click "Details" and select the "Startup" tab. Then right-click on the application that you want to remove from autorun, and click "Disable."

8. Change default applications



Built-in Windows applications look good on tablets, but on a computer it‚Äôs worth replacing them with more functional ones. You can do this this way: open the ‚ÄúOptions‚Äù in the ‚ÄúStart‚Äù menu, then click on ‚ÄúApplications‚Äù and select ‚ÄúDefault Applications‚Äù. Here you can click on your preferred browser, email client, music and video players and image viewer.
In addition, you can fine-tune your preferred applications by the types of files you want to open. To do this, click "Select standard applications by file type" to associate your programs with individual formats - PDF, DOCX, TXT, and so on.
9. Transfer user folders



Windows 10 stores user data (documents, photos, music and videos) on the same partition of the disk where it is located. And if your system unit is spacious enough, you can leave everything as it is.
But moving user folders to another drive or partition will give you several advantages. First of all, you will stop cluttering the system drive with movies and music, and this is especially important if your OS is installed on a small SSD. And you no longer have to worry about saving your data when reinstalling the system.
To transfer user folders, open ‚ÄúSettings‚Äù and go to ‚ÄúSystem‚Äù ‚Üí ‚ÄúDevice Memory‚Äù, then ‚ÄúChange the location for saving new content.‚Äù Choose on which drive you want to save your data.
10. Connect Windows 10 to your smartphone



This is not necessary, but why not? By connecting your computer to your smartphone, you can send messages and view Android or iPhone notifications right on your desktop, open photos from your phone and send links from mobile browsers to Edge on your desktop.
To do this, open ‚ÄúSettings‚Äù ‚Üí ‚ÄúPhone‚Äù and click ‚ÄúAdd Phone‚Äù. Choose which smartphone to associate Windows 10 with Android or iPhone. If necessary, log in to your Microsoft account. Enter the phone number - they will send you a link to the application. After clicking on it, install the program from Google Play and enter the username and password. Then follow the instructions of the application to grant it the necessary rights, and your phone and computer will be connected to each other.
11. Create a recovery point



Now that you‚Äôve practically completed the setup of the new Windows, it would be nice to save your progress so that in case of malfunctions your work will not go missing. To do this, create a Windows restore point and configure the system so that it periodically creates such points itself.
To do this, click the "Start" button and enter "Control Panel", and then go to "System and Security" ‚Üí "System". Open System Protection in the left pane. Click "Recovery Options", enable the creation of recovery points and specify how much space you want to allocate for them.
Then select ‚ÄúCreate‚Äù below. Enter a description for the recovery point so that you can easily find it if necessary, and wait until it is created. Done. Now, if something is wrong with your system, you can easily restore it.

12. Set up backup



There are many backup programs available, including commercial solutions from Acronis and Paragon. But Windows 10 also has a built-in backup tool.
To use it, open ‚ÄúOptions‚Äù and click ‚ÄúUpdate and Security‚Äù ‚Üí ‚ÄúArchive Service‚Äù. Then add the disk where you want to place the backups, and configure the frequency of their creation.
Your Windows 10 is now ready for use.
